body_html:
Hey, thanks for reporting this. I haven't personally tried using the C++ API on Windows yet, but was planning on doing so in the next couple weeks. . In this case you may be missing an include path pointing at torch/csrc/api/include so that torch/torch.h resolves correctly.

For building, we will soon (by end of month) provide .zip archives you can download that contain all relevant headers and shared libraries, which means you won't have to build PyTorch from source to use the C++ API. For now, I would recommend using tools/build_libtorch.py in such a manner:

cd pytorch
mkdir cpp-build
cd cpp-build
python ../tools/build_libtorch.py

This should produce a libtorch DLL that you can use. If that doesn't work, we will fix it.

This process will become a lot smoother very soon -- the C++ API isn't officially released yet so it's a bit rough right now :)

body:
Hey, thanks for reporting this. I haven't personally tried using the C++ API on Windows yet, but was planning on doing so in the next couple weeks. . In this case you may be missing an include path pointing at `torch/csrc/api/include` so that  `torch/torch.h` resolves correctly.

For building, we will soon (by end of month) provide `.zip` archives you can download that contain all relevant headers and shared libraries, which means you won't have to build PyTorch from source to use the C++ API. For now, I would recommend using `tools/build_libtorch.py` in such a manner:

```
cd pytorch
mkdir cpp-build
cd cpp-build
python ../tools/build_libtorch.py
```

This should produce a libtorch DLL that you can use. If that doesn't work, we will fix it.

This process will become a lot smoother very soon -- the C++ API isn't officially released yet so it's a bit rough right now :)
